Get started: Pre-implantation embryo development in human and mouse

Yutong Wang

2019-02-15

Source: vignettes/corgi.Rmd
corgi.Rmd

We illustrate the CorGI feature selection method by analyzing datasets on human and mouse pre-implantation embryo development.

library(corgi)
library(ggplot2)
library(cowplot)

Preprocessing the data

We download the data from the Hemberg Lab website. The human dataset is from Yan et al 2013 while the mouse dataset is from Deng et al 2014.

yan <- readRDS(url("https://scrnaseq-public-datasets.s3.amazonaws.com/scater-objects/yan.rds"))
deng <- readRDS(url("https://scrnaseq-public-datasets.s3.amazonaws.com/scater-objects/deng-reads.rds"))

Get genes common to both datasets

rownames(yan) <- toupper(rownames(yan))
rownames(deng) <- toupper(rownames(deng))
shared_genes <- intersect(rownames(yan), rownames(deng))

Get rid of the spike-in genes

shared_genes <- shared_genes[-grep("ERCC",shared_genes)]

Subset the data

yan <- yan[shared_genes, ]
deng <- deng[shared_genes, ]

Run CorGI feature selection

Normalization is not necessary for running CorGI

set.seed(0)
corgi_output_embyro_devel <-
  run_corgi(logcounts(yan), logcounts(deng))

Select top CorGI genes

corgi_gene_set <-
  union(
    select_top_corgi_genes(corgi_output_embyro_devel, n = 100, SVG_use = 2),
    select_top_corgi_genes(corgi_output_embyro_devel, n = 100, SVG_use = 3)
  )

Visualization

Metadata for the combined datasets

combined <- cbind(logcounts(yan), logcounts(deng))
cell_type <-
  forcats::fct_c(as.factor(yan$cell_type1), as.factor(deng$cell_type1))
cell_type <-
  factor(cell_type,
         levels = c("zygote", "2cell", "4cell", "8cell", "16cell", "blast"))
batch <- c(rep("Human", ncol(yan)), rep("Mouse", ncol(deng)))

Wrapper around the qplot ggplot2::qplot function with our color scheme

my_color_palette <- c("#000000", "#E69F00", "#56B4E9", "#009E73", "#F0E442", "#0072B2", "#D55E00", "#CC79A7")
my_shape_palette <- c(16,1)
qplot <- function(...){
  ggplot2::qplot(...) +
    scale_color_manual(values = my_color_palette) +
    scale_shape_manual(values = my_shape_palette)
}

color_legend <- get_color_legend(cell_type, my_color_palette, legend.position = "bottom",ncol = 6)
batch_legend <- get_shape_legend(batch, my_shape_palette)

Multidimensional scaling (MDS)

axes_legend <- get_axes_legend("MDS")

mds_all <- spearman_rho_mds(combined)
plt_all <- plot_dimensionality_reduction(mds_all, batch, cell_type)+
  ggtitle("No gene filter")


mds_corgi <- spearman_rho_mds(combined[corgi_gene_set, ])
plt_corgi <- plot_dimensionality_reduction(mds_corgi, batch, cell_type)+
  ggtitle("CorGI gene filter")

plot_grid(
  plot_grid(
    plt_all,
    plt_corgi,
    plot_grid(axes_legend, batch_legend, nrow = 2), 
    nrow = 1,
    rel_widths = c(3, 3, 1)
  ),
  color_legend,
  nrow = 2,
  rel_heights = c(4,1)
)

On CorGI genes

Principal component analysis (PCA)

To use PCA, we first need to adjust the read-depth to be comparable across the two datasets

library(scran)
out <- multiBatchNorm(yan, deng, assay.type = "logcounts")
yan <- out[[1]]
deng <- out[[2]]
combined <- cbind(logcounts(yan), logcounts(deng))
axes_legend <- get_axes_legend("PC")

pc_all <- prcomp(t(combined), rank. = 2)$x
plt_all <- plot_dimensionality_reduction(pc_all, batch, cell_type)+
  ggtitle("No gene filter")


pc_corgi <- prcomp(t(combined[corgi_gene_set, ]), rank. = 2)$x
plt_corgi <- plot_dimensionality_reduction(pc_corgi, batch, cell_type)+
  ggtitle("CorGI gene filter")

plot_grid(
  plot_grid(
    plt_all,
    plt_corgi,
    plot_grid(axes_legend, batch_legend, nrow = 2), 
    nrow = 1,
    rel_widths = c(3, 3, 1)
  ),
  color_legend,
  nrow = 2,
  rel_heights = c(4,1)
)
